content.thinking: The user wants me to look at the "cage" implementation in the kawarimidoll/dotfiles repository and incorporate it into this project (dotnix). Let me first explore what "cage" means in that context.

content.text: まず、kawarimidoll/dotfiles の cage 実装を調査します。

1→snippets:
     2→  - name: Make directory and move into that
     3→    keyword: mkcd
     4→    snippet: mkdir -p {{dir_name}} && cd "$_"
     5→
     6→  - name: Make tmp directory, move into that and git init
     7→    keyword: cds
     8→    snippet: cd "$(mktemp -d)" && git init
     9→
    10→  - name: "null"
    11→    keyword: "null"
    12→    snippet: ">/dev/null 2>&1"
    13→    # auto expand condition
    14→    # If not defined, it is only valid at the beginning of a line.
    15→    context:
    16→      # buffer: ''
    17→      lbuffer: '.+\s'
    18→      # rbuffer: ''
    19→
    20→  # Regular abbreviations
    21→  - name: cd previous
    22→    keyword: "-"
    23→    snippet: cd -
    24→
    25→  - name: list path
    26→    keyword: path
    27→    snippet: echo $PATH | tr ':' '\n'
    28→
    29→  - name: list fpath
    30→    keyword: fpath
    31→    snippet: echo $FPATH | tr ':' '\n'
    32→
    33→  - name: bun list packages
    34→    keyword: list
    35→    snippet: pm ls
    36→    context:
    37→      lbuffer: '^bun\s+'
    38→
    39→  - keyword: arto
    40→    snippet: open -a Arto
    41→
    42→  - keyword: cala
    43→    snippet: cage claude
    44→
    45→  - keyword: caha
    46→    snippet: cage happy
    47→
    48→  - name: claude with caffeinate
    49→    keyword: cld
    50→    snippet: caffeinate -i claude
    51→
    52→  - keyword: lg
    53→    snippet: lazygit
    54→
    55→  - keyword: ld
    56→    snippet: lazydocker
    57→
    58→  - name: difit
    59→    keyword: prit
    60→    snippet: difit HEAD origin/main
    61→
    62→  # Global abbreviations (work anywhere in the line)
    63→  - name: pipe ripgrep
    64→    keyword: G
    65→    snippet: "| rg"
    66→    context:
    67→      lbuffer: '.+\s'
    68→
    69→  - name: pipe less
    70→    keyword: L
    71→    snippet: "| less"
    72→    context:
    73→      lbuffer: '.+\s'
    74→
    75→  - name: pipe tee pbcopy with stderr
    76→    keyword: CP
    77→    snippet: "|& tee >(pbcopy)"
    78→    context:
    79→      lbuffer: '.+\s'
    80→
    81→  - name: pipe ripgrep with stderr
    82→    keyword: EG
    83→    snippet: "|& rg"
    84→    context:
    85→      lbuffer: '.+\s'
    86→
    87→  - name: pipe less with stderr
    88→    keyword: EL
    89→    snippet: "|& less"
    90→    context:
    91→      lbuffer: '.+\s'
    92→
    93→  - name: pipe tee pbcopy
    94→    keyword: ECP
    95→    snippet: "| tee >(pbcopy)"
    96→    context:
    97→      lbuffer: '.+\s'
    98→
    99→  - name: redirect stderr to null
   100→    keyword: NE
   101→    snippet: "2> /dev/null"
   102→    context:
   103→      lbuffer: '.+\s'
   104→
   105→  - name: redirect all to null
   106→    keyword: NL
   107→    snippet: "> /dev/null 2>&1"
   108→    context:
   109→      lbuffer: '.+\s'
   110→
   111→  - name: dev null path
   112→    keyword: "/dn"
   113→    snippet: "/dev/null 2>&1"
   114→    context:
   115→      lbuffer: '.+\s'
   116→
   117→completions:
   118→  # just command recipes
   119→  - name: just recipes
   120→    patterns:
   121→      - "^just( .*)? $"
   122→    sourceCommand: "just --summary | tr ' ' '\\n'"
   123→    options:
   124→      --height: 40%
   125→      --cycle: true
   126→      --select-1: true
   127→      --prompt: "'just> '"
   128→      --preview: "just --show {}"
   129→
   130→  - name: fuzzy find and edit
   131→    patterns:
   132→      - "^vim?( .*)? $"
   133→      - "^nv(im)?( .*)? $"
   134→    sourceCommand: "fffe -f"
   135→    options:
   136→      --height: 40%
   137→      --cycle: true
   138→      --select-1: true
   139→      --multi: true
   140→      --prompt: "'file> '"
   141→      --preview: "fffe -p {}"
   142→
   143→  - name: package scripts
   144→    patterns:
   145→      - "^nr(?: .*)? $"
   146→      - "^npm run(?: .*)? $"
   147→      - "^yarn run(?: .*)? $"
   148→      - "^pnpm run(?: .*)? $"
   149→      - "^bun run(?: .*)? $"
   150→    sourceCommand: 'npm run --json 2>/dev/null | jq -r ''keys | .[]'''
   151→    options:
   152→      --prompt: "'npm run > '"
   153→      --height: 40%
   154→      --cycle: true
   155→      --select-1: true
   156→      --preview: "npm run --json 2>/dev/null | jq -r '.\\\"{}\\\"'"
   157→      --preview-window: "up:1:wrap"
   158→
   159→  - name: deno task
   160→    patterns:
   161→      - "^deno task(?: .*)? $"
   162→    sourceCommand: "NO_COLOR=1 deno task 2>&1 | rg -o '^- (.*)' -r '$1'"
   163→    options:
   164→      --prompt: "'deno task> '"
   165→      --height: 40%
   166→      --cycle: true
   167→      --select-1: true
   168→      # xargsを無引数で使うと前後のwhitespaceをtrimできる
   169→      --preview: "NO_COLOR=1 deno task 2>&1 | rg -A 1 '^- {}$' | tail -n 1 | xargs"
   170→      --preview-window: "up:1:wrap"
   171→
   172→  # simple sourceCommand, no callback
   173→  - name: kill signal
   174→    patterns:
   175→      - "^kill -s $"
   176→    sourceCommand: "kill -l | tr ' ' '\\n'"
   177→    options:
   178→      --prompt: "'Kill Signal> '"
   179→
   180→  # use excludePatterns and callback
   181→  - name: kill pid
   182→    patterns:
   183→      - "^kill( .*)? $"
   184→    excludePatterns:
   185→      # -l, -n or -s is followed by SIGNAL instead of PID
   186→      - " -[lns] $"
   187→    sourceCommand: "LANG=C ps -ef | sed 1d"
   188→    options:
   189→      --multi: true
   190→      --prompt: "'Kill Process> '"
   191→    callback: "awk '{print $2}'"
   192→
   193→  # Use null (\0) termination Input / Output
   194→  - name: chdir
   195→    patterns:
   196→      - "^cd $"
   197→    sourceCommand: "fd --type d --hidden --exclude .git --max-depth 5 --print0"
   198→    options:
   199→      # Added --read0 if null termination is used in `sourceCommand` output.
   200→      --read0: true
   201→      --prompt: "'Chdir> '"
   202→      --preview: "eza -1a --icons --color=always {}"
   203→    callback: "cut -z -c 3-"
   204→    callbackZero: true # null termination is used in `callback` I/O
   205→
   206→  - name: env
   207→    patterns:
   208→      - "\\$$"
   209→    sourceCommand: "printenv | sed -e 's/=.*//'"
   210→    options:
   211→      --prompt: "'Env> '"
   212→
   213→  - name: jobs
   214→    patterns:
   215→      - "^fg $"
   216→    sourceCommand: "jobs"
   217→    callback: "awk -F'[][]' '{print \"%\" $2}'"
   218→    options:
   219→      --prompt: "'Jobs> '"
   220→
   221→  - name: difit
   222→    patterns:
   223→      - "^difit $"
   224→    sourceCommand: "git --no-pager log --oneline"
   225→    callback: "sed 's/ .*//'"
   226→    options:
   227→      --prompt: "'Commits> '"
   228→      --no-sort: true
   229→      --no-multi: true
   230→      --preview: "echo {} | sed 's/ .*//' | xargs --no-run-if-empty git show --color=always"
   231→

1→{
     2→  inputs,
     3→  lib,
     4→  config,
     5→  pkgs,
     6→  ...
     7→}:
     8→let
     9→  username = "kawarimidoll";
    10→in
    11→{
    12→  nixpkgs = {
    13→    overlays = [
    14→      (inputs.vim-overlay.overlays.features {
    15→        compiledby = "kawarimidoll-nix";
    16→        lua = true;
    17→        cscope = true;
    18→        sodium = true;
    19→        ruby = true;
    20→        python3 = true;
    21→      })
    22→      inputs.neovim-nightly-overlay.overlays.default
    23→    ];
    24→    config = {
    25→      allowUnfreePredicate =
    26→        pkg:
    27→        builtins.elem (lib.getName pkg) [
    28→          "claude-code"
    29→          "coderabbit-cli"
    30→          "copilot-cli"
    31→        ];
    32→    };
    33→  };
    34→
    35→  home = {
    36→    username = username;
    37→    homeDirectory = "/Users/${username}";
    38→
    39→    sessionVariables = {
    40→      DOT_DIR = "${config.home.homeDirectory}/dotfiles";
    41→    };
    42→
    43→    # https://nixos.wiki/wiki/FAQ/When_do_I_update_stateVersion
    44→    stateVersion = "24.11";
    45→
    46→    packages =
    47→      let
    48→        system = pkgs.stdenv.hostPlatform.system;
    49→        koi = inputs.koi.packages.${system}.default;
    50→        cage = inputs.cage.packages.${system}.default;
    51→        arto = inputs.arto.packages.${system}.default;
    52→        version-lsp = inputs.version-lsp.packages.${system}.default;
    53→        hjkls = inputs.hjkls.packages.${system}.default;
    54→        nur = inputs.nur-packages.packages.${system};
    55→        llm-agents = inputs.llm-agents.packages.${system};
    56→      in
    57→      with pkgs;
    58→      [
    59→        koi
    60→        cage
    61→        arto
    62→        hjkls
    63→        version-lsp
    64→
    65→        llm-agents.agent-browser
    66→        llm-agents.claude-code
    67→        llm-agents.codex
    68→        llm-agents.coderabbit-cli
    69→        llm-agents.copilot-cli
    70→        llm-agents.copilot-language-server
    71→        llm-agents.happy-coder
    72→
    73→        nur.difit
    74→        nur.ghost
    75→        nur.jsmigemo
    76→        nur.kakehashi
    77→        nur.lolcrab
    78→        nur.plamo-translate
    79→        nur.rustmigemo
    80→        nur.rxpipes
    81→        nur.stormy
    82→
    83→        act
    84→        ad
    85→        asciiquarium
    86→        ast-grep
    87→        astroterm
    88→        atuin
    89→        bash-language-server
    90→        beautysh
    91→        binutils

content.content:
1→# 基本設定
     2→setopt always_last_prompt   # 補完候補が表示されるときにプロンプトを移動させない
     3→setopt auto_cd              # ディレクトリ名だけでcd
     4→setopt auto_list            # 補完候補を一覧表示に
     5→setopt auto_menu            # 補完候補をtabで選択
     6→setopt bsd_echo             # echoをbash互換にする なおデフォルトはecho -eに相当
     7→setopt complete_in_word     # 単語の途中でも補完を行う
     8→setopt correct              # コマンドのスペルミスを指摘
     9→setopt extended_glob        # 拡張グロブを有効化
    10→setopt globdots             # 補完時にドットファイルも候補に表示
    11→setopt interactive_comments # コンソールでも#をコメントと解釈
    12→setopt mark_dirs            # dirs/d*<tab> → dirs/d1/ dirs/d2/ のように補完結果のディレクトリ末尾に/をつける
    13→setopt multios              # 複数のリダイレクトを有効化（例: cmd > file1 > file2）
    14→setopt nonomatch            # 引数の#とかをファイル名として認識するのを防止
    15→setopt print_eight_bit      # 日本語ファイル名を表示する
    16→# setopt ksh_arrays # 配列の添字を0から開始 むしろなんでzshは1から始まる設定なの…
    17→
    18→# History設定
    19→HISTFILE="${XDG_DATA_HOME:-$HOME/.local/share}/zsh/history"
    20→HISTSIZE=10000
    21→SAVEHIST=10000
    22→setopt append_history       # 履歴を追記
    23→setopt hist_ignore_all_dups # 重複を記録しない
    24→setopt hist_ignore_dups     # 重複を記録しない
    25→setopt hist_save_no_dups    # 重複を記録しない
    26→setopt hist_reduce_blanks   # 余分なスペースを削除
    27→setopt hist_ignore_space    # スペースで開始したコマンドを記録しない
    28→setopt hist_verify          # 履歴使用時に編集
    29→setopt share_history        # セッション間で履歴を共有
    30→
    31→# Historyディレクトリ作成
    32→[[ -d "${HISTFILE:h}" ]] || mkdir -p "${HISTFILE:h}"
    33→
    34→# [zshで特定のコマンドをヒストリに追加しない条件を柔軟に設定する - mollifier delta blog](https://mollifier.hatenablog.com/entry/20090728/p1)
    35→zshaddhistory() {
    36→  local line=${1%%$'\n'}  # 末尾の改行を削除
    37→  local cmd=${line%% *}   # 最初の単語（コマンド名）を取得
    38→
    39→  # 存在しないコマンドをヒストリに追加しない（サブコマンドの存在までは確認されない）
    40→  # 指定したコマンドをヒストリに追加しない
    41→  [[ "$(command -v $cmd)" != '' && ${cmd} != (man|brew|rgf|nv|nvim|vi|vim) ]]
    42→}
    43→

     4→
     5→# zmv with noglob and -W option
     6→autoload -Uz zmv
     7→alias zmv='noglob zmv -W'
     8→
     9→# キャッシュファイルの場所
    10→zstyle ':completion:*' cache-path "${XDG_CACHE_HOME}/zsh/zcompcache"
    11→
    12→# 補完時に大文字小文字を区別しない
    13→zstyle ':completion:*' matcher-list 'm:{a-z}={A-Z}'
    14→
    15→# 現在のディレクトリを補完しない
    16→zstyle ':completion:*' ignore-parents parent pwd ..
    17→
    18→# sudoの後ろでコマンドを補完
    19→zstyle ':completion:*:sudo:*' command-path /usr/local/sbin /usr/local/bin \
    20→  /usr/sbin /usr/bin /sbin /bin
    21→
    22→# 区切り文字としたい記号をWORDCHARSから除く
    23→# vimでいうiskeywordの逆
    24→# M-f, M-b, ^w などの動作に影響する
    25→typeset -g WORDCHARS="${WORDCHARS//[\/=]/}"
    26→
    27→bindkey -e
    28→bindkey "^[[Z" reverse-menu-complete # Shift-Tabで補完候補を逆順
    29→
    30→bindkey "^P" history-substring-search-up
    31→bindkey "^N" history-substring-search-down
    32→
    33→# c-[/c-]でvimのf/Fのように文字検索
    34→bindkey '^]' vi-find-next-char
    35→bindkey '^[' vi-find-prev-char
    36→
    37→bindkey '^X^R' redo
    38→bindkey '^[[61;5u' redo # Ctrl+=
    39→
    40→bindkey ' '      zeno-auto-snippet
    41→bindkey '^m'     zeno-auto-snippet-and-accept-line
    42→bindkey '^i'     zeno-completion
    43→bindkey '^x '    zeno-insert-space
    44→bindkey '^x^m'   accept-line
    45→bindkey '^x^z'   zeno-toggle-auto-snippet
    46→bindkey '^r'     zeno-smart-history-selection
    47→bindkey '^x^a'   zeno-insert-snippet
    48→# bindkey '^x^f'   zeno-ghq-cd
    49→
    50→# ghq + fzf でリポジトリに移動
    51→ghq-cd-widget() {
    52→local dir
    53→dir=$(ghq list | fzf --no-multi --exit-0 --preview="ls -FA1 $(ghq root)/{}")
    54→if [ -n "$dir" ]; then
    55→  BUFFER="cd $(ghq root)/$dir"
    56→  zle redisplay
    57→  zle accept-line
    58→else
    59→  zle redisplay
    60→fi
    61→}
    62→zle -N ghq-cd-widget
    63→bindkey '^x^f' ghq-cd-widget
    64→
    65→# [zshのコマンドラインを任意のテキストエディタで編集する - Qiita](https://qiita.com/mollifier/items/7b1cfe609a7911a69706)
    66→autoload -Uz edit-command-line
    67→zle -N edit-command-line
    68→edit_current_line() {
    69→  EDITOR="vim -c 'setl awa|norm!G$'" zle edit-command-line
    70→}
    71→zle -N edit_current_line
    72→bindkey '^xe' edit_current_line
    73→bindkey '^x^e' edit_current_line
    74→
    75→oneliners() {
    76→  local oneliner=$(__get_oneliners) || return 1
    77→  # ZLEコンテキストかどうかを判定
    78→  if zle; then
    79→    # ZLEウィジェットとして動作：現在のバッファに挿入
    80→    local before_cursor="${oneliner%%__CURSOR__*}"
    81→    BUFFER="${oneliner//__CURSOR__/}"
    82→    CURSOR="${#before_cursor}"
    83→    zle redisplay
    84→  else
    85→    # 通常コマンドとして動作：次のプロンプトに挿入
    86→    print -z "${oneliner//__CURSOR__/}"
    87→  fi
    88→}
    89→zle -N oneliners
    90→bindkey '^xo' oneliners
    91→bindkey '^x^o' oneliners
    92→
    93→# カスタムZLEウィジェット
    94→# 参考: zshで範囲選択・削除・コピー・切り取りする - Qiita
    95→# https://qiita.com/takc923/items/35d9fe81f61436c867a8
    96→
    97→# quote-word: カーソル位置の単語をクォート
    98→quote-word() {
    99→  zle select-a-word
   100→  zle quote-region
   101→}
   102→zle -N quote-word
   103→
   104→# backward-delete-char-or-region: 選択中は範囲削除、通常時はautopair-delete
   105→backward-delete-char-or-region() {
   106→  if [ $REGION_ACTIVE -eq 0 ]; then
   107→    zle autopair-delete
   108→  else
   109→    zle kill-region
   110→  fi
   111→}
   112→zle -N backward-delete-char-or-region
   113→
   114→# autopairプラグインの後で上書きする必要があるため、zsh-deferで遅延バインド
   115→zsh-defer bindkey '^h' backward-delete-char-or-region
   116→
   117→# delete-char-or-region: 選択中は範囲削除、通常時は直後の1文字削除
   118→delete-char-or-region() {
   119→  if [ $REGION_ACTIVE -eq 0 ]; then
   120→    zle delete-char
   121→  else
   122→    zle kill-region
   123→  fi
   124→}
   125→zle -N delete-char-or-region
   126→bindkey '^d' delete-char-or-region
   127→
   128→# backward-kill-word-or-region: 選択中は範囲切り取り、通常時は単語切り取り
   129→backward-kill-word-or-region() {
   130→  if [ $REGION_ACTIVE -eq 0 ]; then
   131→    zle autopair-delete-word
   132→  else
   133→    zle kill-region
   134→  fi
   135→}
   136→zle -N backward-kill-word-or-region
   137→
   138→# autopairプラグインの後で上書きする必要があるため、zsh-deferで遅延バインド
   139→zsh-defer bindkey '^w' backward-kill-word-or-region
   140→
   141→# backward-kill-to-space: 直前の空白まで削除（Vimの WORD 削除に相当）
   142→backward-kill-to-space() {
   143→  # 末尾の空白文字を全て削除（## = 1回以上の最長マッチ）
   144→  LBUFFER=${LBUFFER%%[[:space:]]##}
   145→  # 末尾の非空白文字を全て削除
   146→  LBUFFER=${LBUFFER%%[^[:space:]]##}
   147→}
   148→zle -N backward-kill-to-space
   149→bindkey '^[[119;6u' backward-kill-to-space  # Ctrl+Shift+w
   150→
   151→# copy-region-and-deactivate: 範囲コピーして選択終了
   152→copy-region-and-deactivate() {
   153→  if [ $REGION_ACTIVE -ne 0 ]; then
   154→    zle copy-region-as-kill
   155→    REGION_ACTIVE=0
   156→  fi
   157→}
   158→zle -N copy-region-and-deactivate
   159→bindkey '^[W' copy-region-and-deactivate
   160→bindkey '^[w' copy-region-and-deactivate
   161→
   162→# delete-last-argument: コマンドラインの最後の引数を削除
   163→# https://eiji.page/blog/zsh-delete-last-argument/
   164→function delete_last_argument() {
   165→  # コマンドラインをシェルのパースに基づいて配列化
   166→  local tokens=("${(z)BUFFER}")
   167→  (( ${#tokens} > 1 )) || return
   168→  # 最後の引数を除いて結合
   169→  BUFFER="${(j: :)${tokens[1,-2]}}"
   170→}
   171→zle -N delete_last_argument
   172→bindkey "^Xw" delete_last_argument
   173→
   174→# quote-word-or-region: 選択中はquote-region、通常時はquote-word
   175→quote-word-or-region() {
   176→  if [ $REGION_ACTIVE -eq 0 ]; then
   177→    zle quote-word
   178→  else
   179→    zle quote-region
   180→  fi
   181→}
   182→zle -N quote-word-or-region
   183→bindkey '^[[39;5u' quote-word-or-region  # Ctrl+'
   184→
   185→# https://github.com/mdumitru/fancy-ctrl-z/blob/master/fancy-ctrl-z.zsh
   186→# https://gist.github.com/yuki-yano/f1f0d11db6d1d49180bca7e282599932
   187→fancy-ctrl-z () {
   188→  if [[ $#BUFFER -eq 0 ]]; then
   189→    BUFFER=" fg"
   190→    zle accept-line
   191→  else
   192→    zle push-input
   193→    zle clear-screen
   194→  fi
   195→}
   196→zle -N fancy-ctrl-z
   197→bindkey '^Z' fancy-ctrl-z
   198→
   199→autoload -Uz add-zsh-hook
   200→
   201→# Set tab name of kitty https://github.com/kovidgoyal/kitty/issues/930
   202→__kitty_tab_title_precmd() {
   203→  print -Pn "\e]0;%~\a"
   204→}
   205→add-zsh-hook precmd __kitty_tab_title_precmd

content.content:
# Cage: A Security Sandbox CLI Tool

**Cage** is a cross-platform command-line utility that executes commands within a restricted sandbox environment. It allows programs to read files freely while blocking write operations to the filesystem—unless explicitly permitted.

## Core Purpose

The tool addresses scenarios where you need to run potentially untrusted code or scripts safely without risking unintended system modifications. It enables developers to analyze suspicious programs, process sensitive data with controlled outputs, and restrict build processes to specific directories.

## Main Features

- **Write-only restrictions**: Commands retain full read and execute permissions but cannot modify files except in allowed locations
- **Cross-platform support**: Functions on Linux (kernel 5.13+) and macOS using platform-specific mechanisms
- **Flexible allowlisting**: Grant write access to specific paths via command-line flags or configuration files
- **Configuration system**: Define reusable presets for common tools like npm and cargo
- **Debug mode**: Disable all restrictions with a single flag for troubleshooting
- **Process replacement**: Uses syscall.Exec to prevent sandbox circumvention
- **Environment detection**: Sets the IN_CAGE variable so applications can detect sandboxed execution

## Implementation Approach

Linux leverages Landlock LSM security features, while macOS uses sandbox-exec with custom profiles. The tool maintains transparency by directly replacing the process rather than spawning a wrapper, ensuring authentic command execution within defined constraints.

content.content:
# Cage: Security Sandbox CLI Tool

## Overview

Cage is a cross-platform security sandbox CLI tool that executes commands with restricted file system write access while maintaining full read permissions. It's designed to safely run untrusted code, limit file system modifications during development, analyze potentially dangerous scripts, and process sensitive data with controlled outputs.

## Key Features

- **Write-only restriction**: Commands can read any file but cannot write unless explicitly allowed
- **Cross-platform support**: Works on Linux (kernel 5.13+) and macOS
- **Flexible permissions**: Grant write access to specific paths via `-allow` flags
- **Debug mode**: Disable all restrictions with `-allow-all`
- **Transparent execution**: Uses `syscall.Exec` to replace the process, preventing sandbox bypass

## Installation

### Homebrew (macOS)
```bash
brew install --cask Warashi/tap/cage --no-quarantine
```

### Go Install
```bash
go install github.com/Warashi/cage@latest
```

### From Source
```bash
git clone https://github.com/Warashi/cage
cd cage
go build
```

## Basic Usage

**Syntax:**
```bash
cage [flags] <command> [args...]
```

**Common Flags:**
- `-allow <path>`: Grant write access to specific paths (repeatable)
- `-allow-keychain`: Allow macOS keychain write access
- `-allow-git`: Enable git operations in worktrees
- `-allow-all`: Disable all restrictions (debug mode)
- `-preset <name>`: Apply predefined configurations
- `-list-presets`: Display available presets
- `-config <path>`: Custom configuration file path

## Usage Examples

**Temporary directory access:**
```bash
cage -allow /tmp python analyze.py input.txt
```

**Restricted build outputs:**
```bash
cage -allow ./build -allow ./dist -- npm run build
```

**Safe script analysis:**
```bash
cage python suspicious_script.py
```

**Controlled data processing:**
```bash
cage -allow ./output -- ./process_data.sh /sensitive/data
```

**macOS keychain access:**
```bash
cage -allow-keychain -- security add-generic-password -s "MyService" -a "username" -w
```

**Git operations in worktrees:**
```bash
cage -allow-git -allow . -- git checkout -b new-feature
```

**Using presets:**
```bash
cage -preset npm npm install
cage -preset cargo cargo build
cage -list-presets
```

## Configuration Files

Cage supports YAML configuration files for defining presets. Search locations:
- Path specified with `-config` flag
- `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/cage/presets.yaml` (Linux)
- `$HOME/Library/Application Support/cage/` (macOS)
- `%APPDATA%\cage\` (Windows)

**Example configuration:**
```yaml
presets:
  npm:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "$HOME/.npm"
      - "$HOME/.cache/npm"
  
  cargo:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "$HOME/.cargo"
      - "$HOME/.rustup"
```

### Symlink Evaluation

Paths support an `eval-symlinks` option for resolving symlinks:
```yaml
presets:
  macos-tmp:
    allow:
      - path: "/tmp"
        eval-symlinks: true
```

### Auto-Presets

Automatically apply presets based on executed commands:
```yaml
auto-presets:
  - command: npm
    presets:
      - npm
  
  - command-pattern: ^(npm|yarn|npx)$
    presets:
      - npm
```

## Platform Implementation

**Linux:** Uses Landlock LSM (kernel 5.13+), granting read/execute access to entire filesystem with write-only access to `/dev/null` and explicitly allowed paths.

**macOS:** Uses `sandbox-exec` with custom profiles denying all writes except to allowed paths; supports keychain access via `-allow-keychain`.

## Environment Variables

**IN_CAGE:** Automatically set to `1` when commands run inside cage, allowing programs to detect sandbox context.

```bash
if [ "$IN_CAGE" = "1" ]; then
  echo "Running inside cage sandbox"
fi
```

## Homebrew Integration

On macOS, modify `.zprofile` to avoid `shellenv` errors:
```bash
if [[ -z $IN_CAGE ]]; then
  eval "$(brew shellenv)"
fi
```

## Security Policy

| Operation | Default | With -allow |
|-----------|---------|------------|
| File Read | ✅ Allowed | ✅ Allowed |
| File Write | ❌ Denied | ✅ Allowed for specified paths |
| File Execute | ✅ Allowed | ✅ Allowed |
| Network | ✅ Allowed | ✅ Allowed |
| Processes | ✅ Allowed | ✅ Allowed |

## Development

**Build:**
```bash
go build
```

**Testing:**
```bash
./test_e2e.sh
```

**Nix environment:**
```bash
nix develop
```

## Common Use Cases

1. **Development Workflows**: Restrict build outputs to specific directories
2. **Security Testing**: Safely analyze potentially malicious scripts
3. **Data Processing**: Process sensitive data with controlled outputs
4. **LLM Code Agents**: Safe execution of AI-generated commands

## Limitations

Sandboxing is only implemented on Linux and macOS. Other platforms return an error indicating sandboxing is unavailable.

## License & Contributing

See the repository for licensing information and contribution guidelines.

1→snippets:
     2→  - name: Make directory and move into that
     3→    keyword: mkcd

     5→
     6→  - name: Make tmp directory, move into that and git init

     9→
    10→  - name: "null"
    11→    keyword: "null"
    12→    snippet: ">/dev/null 2>&1"
    13→    # auto expand condition
    14→    # If not defined, it is only valid at the beginning of a line.
    15→    context:
    16→      # buffer: ''
    17→      lbuffer: '.+\s'
    18→      # rbuffer: ''
    19→
    20→  # Regular abbreviations
    21→  - name: cd previous
    22→    keyword: "-"
    23→    snippet: cd -
    24→
    25→  - name: list path

    57→

    59→    keyword: prit

    61→
    62→  # Global abbreviations (work anywhere in the line)

    65→    snippet: "| rg"

    67→      lbuffer: '.+\s'
    68→
    69→  - name: pipe less

    71→    snippet: "| less"

    77→    snippet: "|& tee >(pbcopy)"

    80→

    85→      lbuffer: '.+\s'
    86→

    92→

    99→  - name: redirect stderr to null
   100→    keyword: NE
   101→    snippet: "2> /dev/null"
   102→    context:
   103→      lbuffer: '.+\s'
   104→
   105→  - name: redirect all to null
   106→    keyword: NL
   107→    snippet: "> /dev/null 2>&1"
   108→    context:
   109→      lbuffer: '.+\s'
   110→
   111→  - name: dev null path
   112→    keyword: "/dn"
   113→    snippet: "/dev/null 2>&1"
   114→    context:
   115→      lbuffer: '.+\s'
   116→
   117→completions:
   118→  # just command recipes
   119→  - name: just recipes
   120→    patterns:
   121→      - "^just( .*)? $"
   122→    sourceCommand: "just --summary | tr ' ' '\\n'"
   123→    options:
   124→      --height: 40%
   125→      --cycle: true
   126→      --select-1: true
   127→      --prompt: "'just> '"
   128→      --preview: "just --show {}"
   129→
   130→  - name: fuzzy find and edit
   131→    patterns:
   132→      - "^vim?( .*)? $"
   133→      - "^nv(im)?( .*)? $"
   134→    sourceCommand: "fffe -f"
   135→    options:
   136→      --height: 40%
   137→      --cycle: true
   138→      --select-1: true
   139→      --multi: true
   140→      --prompt: "'file> '"
   141→      --preview: "fffe -p {}"
   142→
   143→  - name: package scripts
   144→    patterns:
   145→      - "^nr(?: .*)? $"
   146→      - "^npm run(?: .*)? $"
   147→      - "^yarn run(?: .*)? $"
   148→      - "^pnpm run(?: .*)? $"
   149→      - "^bun run(?: .*)? $"
   150→    sourceCommand: 'npm run --json 2>/dev/null | jq -r ''keys | .[]'''
   151→    options:
   152→      --prompt: "'npm run > '"
   153→      --height: 40%
   154→      --cycle: true
   155→      --select-1: true
   156→      --preview: "npm run --json 2>/dev/null | jq -r '.\\\"{}\\\"'"
   157→      --preview-window: "up:1:wrap"
   158→
   159→  - name: deno task
   160→    patterns:
   161→      - "^deno task(?: .*)? $"
   162→    sourceCommand: "NO_COLOR=1 deno task 2>&1 | rg -o '^- (.*)' -r '$1'"
   163→    options:
   164→      --prompt: "'deno task> '"
   165→      --height: 40%
   166→      --cycle: true
   167→      --select-1: true
   168→      # xargsを無引数で使うと前後のwhitespaceをtrimできる
   169→      --preview: "NO_COLOR=1 deno task 2>&1 | rg -A 1 '^- {}$' | tail -n 1 | xargs"
   170→      --preview-window: "up:1:wrap"
   171→
   172→  # simple sourceCommand, no callback
   173→  - name: kill signal
   174→    patterns:
   175→      - "^kill -s $"
   176→    sourceCommand: "kill -l | tr ' ' '\\n'"
   177→    options:
   178→      --prompt: "'Kill Signal> '"
   179→
   180→  # use excludePatterns and callback
   181→  - name: kill pid
   182→    patterns:
   183→      - "^kill( .*)? $"
   184→    excludePatterns:
   185→      # -l, -n or -s is followed by SIGNAL instead of PID
   186→      - " -[lns] $"
   187→    sourceCommand: "LANG=C ps -ef | sed 1d"
   188→    options:
   189→      --multi: true
   190→      --prompt: "'Kill Process> '"
   191→    callback: "awk '{print $2}'"
   192→
   193→  # Use null (\0) termination Input / Output
   194→  - name: chdir
   195→    patterns:
   196→      - "^cd $"
   197→    sourceCommand: "fd --type d --hidden --exclude .git --max-depth 5 --print0"
   198→    options:
   199→      # Added --read0 if null termination is used in `sourceCommand` output.
   200→      --read0: true
   201→      --prompt: "'Chdir> '"
   202→      --preview: "eza -1a --icons --color=always {}"
   203→    callback: "cut -z -c 3-"
   204→    callbackZero: true # null termination is used in `callback` I/O
   205→
   206→  - name: env
   207→    patterns:
   208→      - "\\$$"
   209→    sourceCommand: "printenv | sed -e 's/=.*//'"
   210→    options:
   211→      --prompt: "'Env> '"
   212→
   213→  - name: jobs
   214→    patterns:
   215→      - "^fg $"
   216→    sourceCommand: "jobs"
   217→    callback: "awk -F'[][]' '{print \"%\" $2}'"
   218→    options:
   219→      --prompt: "'Jobs> '"
   220→
   221→  - name: difit
   222→    patterns:
   223→      - "^difit $"
   224→    sourceCommand: "git --no-pager log --oneline"
   225→    callback: "sed 's/ .*//'"
   226→    options:
   227→      --prompt: "'Commits> '"
   228→      --no-sort: true
   229→      --no-multi: true
   230→      --preview: "echo {} | sed 's/ .*//' | xargs --no-run-if-empty git show --color=always"
   231→

    10→" @kawarimidoll

    12→" https://github.com/kawarimidoll

    14→let $CACHE = expand('~/.cache')

    24→"-----------------

   113→"-----------------
   114→" Commands and Functions
   115→"-----------------
   116→command! Rcedit edit $MYVIMRC
   117→command! Rcreload write | source $MYVIMRC | nohlsearch | redraw | echo 'init.vim is reloaded.'
   118→command! Deinedit edit ~/.config/nvim/dein.toml

   120→" command! LazyGit tab terminal lazygit

   123→" command! DenoFmt echo system("deno fmt --quiet ".expand("%:p")) | edit | echo 'deno fmt current file'
   124→command! CopyFullPath let @*=expand('%:p') | echo 'copy full path'
   125→command! CopyDirName  let @*=expand('%:h') | echo 'copy dir name'
   126→command! CopyFileName let @*=expand('%:t') | echo 'copy file name'
   127→command! -nargs=* T split | wincmd j | resize 12 | terminal <args>
   128→
   129→" [Vimの生産性を高める12の方法 | POSTD](https://postd.cc/how-to-boost-your-vim-productivity/)
   130→function! s:VisualPaste()
   131→  let clipboard_options = split(&clipboard, ",")
   132→  let restore_reg = index(clipboard_options, "unnamed") >= 0 ? @* : @"
   133→  function! RestoreRegister() closure
   134→    if index(clipboard_options, "unnamed") >= 0
   135→      let @* = restore_reg
   136→      if index(clipboard_options, "unnamedplus") >= 0
   137→        let @+ = restore_reg
   138→      endif
   139→    else
   140→      let @" = restore_reg
   141→    endif
   142→    return ''
   143→  endfunction
   144→  return "p@=RestoreRegister()\<CR>"
   145→endfunction
   146→
   147→" " [vimのマーク機能をできるだけ活用してみる - Make 鮫 noise](http://saihoooooooo.hatenablog.com/entry/2013/04/30/001908)
   148→" let g:mark_chars = ['h', 'j', 'k', 'l']
   149→" function! s:AutoMark() abort
   150→"   let b:mark_pos = exists('b:mark_pos') ? (b:mark_pos + 1) % len(g:mark_chars) : 0
   151→"   execute 'normal! m' . g:mark_chars[b:mark_pos]
   152→"   echo 'auto-marked' g:mark_chars[b:mark_pos]
   153→" endfunction
   154→" function! s:AutoJump() abort
   155→"   if !exists('b:mark_pos')
   156→"     echo 'not auto-marked yet.'
   157→"     return
   158→"   endif
   159→"   execute 'normal! `' . g:mark_chars[b:mark_pos]
   160→"   echo 'jumped to mark' g:mark_chars[b:mark_pos]
   161→" endfunction

   163→" " [neovim terminal](https://gist.github.com/pocari/fd0622fb5ec6946a368e8ee0603979ae)

   165→" function! s:onTermExit(job_id, code, event) dict
   166→"   " Process Exitが表示されたその後cr打つとバッファが無くなるので
   167→"   " それと同じようにする
   168→"   call feedkeys("\<CR>")
   169→" endfun

   171→" function! s:DenoRepl() abort
   172→"   only | echo 'deno repl' | split | wincmd j | resize 12 | execute 'terminal deno'
   173→" endfun

   176→function! s:DenoTerm() abort
   177→  let l:filename = expand('%:p')
   178→  let l:cmd = l:filename =~ '\(\.\|_\)\?test\.\(ts\|tsx\|js\|mjs\|jsx\)$'
   179→   \ ? 'test' : 'run'
   180→  only | echo '' | split | wincmd j | resize 12 |
   181→   \ execute 'terminal deno ' . l:cmd .
   182→   \ ' -A --no-check --unstable --watch ' . l:filename |
   183→   \ stopinsert | execute 'normal! G' |
   184→   \ set bufhidden=wipe | wincmd k
   185→endfun
   186→command! -bang DenoRun call s:DenoTerm()

   188→" braces motion

   190→" [ to effect prev, ] to effect next

   389→"-----------------
   390→" Abbreviations
   391→"-----------------
   392→cabbrev svs saveas %
   393→
   394→"-----------------
   395→" Appearances
   396→"-----------------
   397→syntax enable
   398→
   399→" colorscheme sonokai
   400→
   401→" tablineの項目はwinwidthを気にしなくて良い
   402→" let g:lightline = {
   403→"      \ 'colorscheme': 'sonokai',
   404→"      \ 'active': {
   405→"      \   'left': [['mode', 'paste'], ['coc_info', 'coc_hints', 'coc_errors', 'coc_warnings', 'coc_ok'],
   406→"      \            ['gitgutter', 'filename', 'modified'], ['coc_status'], ['vista']],
   407→"      \   'right': [['coc'], ['lineinfo', 'anzu'], ['percent'], ['fileformat', 'fileencoding', 'filetype']]
   408→"      \ },
   409→"      \ 'tabline': {
   410→"      \  'left': [['tabs']],
   411→"      \  'right': [['pwd']],
   412→"      \ },
   413→"      \ 'component': {
   414→"      \   'fileencoding': '%{winwidth(0) > 70 ? (strlen(&fenc) ? &fenc : &enc) : ""}',
   415→"      \   'fileformat': '%{winwidth(0) > 70 ? &fileformat : ""}',
   416→"      \   'filetype': '%{winwidth(0) > 70 ? (strlen(&filetype) ? &filetype : "no ft") : ""}',
   417→"      \   'mode': '%{winwidth(0) > 60 ? lightline#mode() : lightline#mode()[0]}',
   418→"      \   'modified': '%{!&modifiable ? "RO" : &modified ? "+" : ""}',
   419→"      \   'pwd': '%.35(%{fnamemodify(getcwd(), ":~")}%)',
   420→"      \ },
   421→"      \ 'component_function': {
   422→"      \   'anzu': 'anzu#search_status',
   423→"      \   'coc': 'coc#status',
   424→"      \   'gitgutter': 'LightlineGitGutter',
   425→"      \   'vista': 'LightlineVista',
   426→"      \ },
   427→"      \ }
   428→" call lightline#coc#register()
   429→" [lightline.vimをカスタマイズする - cafegale(LeafCage備忘録)](http://leafcage.hateblo.jp/entry/2013/10/21/lightlinevim-customize)
   430→" [lightline.vim に乗り換えた - すぱぶろ](http://superbrothers.hatenablog.com/entry/2013/08/29/001326)
   431→" function! LightlineGitGutter()
   432→"   if !exists('*GitGutterGetHunkSummary')
   433→"        \ || !get(g:, 'gitgutter_enabled', 0)
   434→"     return ''
   435→"   endif
   436→"   let [a,m,r] = GitGutterGetHunkSummary()
   437→"   let ret = ( a ? g:gitgutter_sign_added . a . ' ' : '' ) .
   438→"        \ ( m ? g:gitgutter_sign_modified . m . ' ' : '' ) .
   439→"        \ ( r ? g:gitgutter_sign_removed . r : '' )
   440→"   return substitute(ret, " $", "", "")
   441→" endfunction
   442→" function! LightlineVista() abort
   443→"   return get(b:, 'vista_nearest_method_or_function', '')
   444→" endfunction
   445→
   446→" 全角スペースの可視化 colorscheme以降に記述する
   447→if has('syntax')
   448→  let s:HighlightZenkakuSpace = {-> execute("highlight ZenkakuSpace cterm=reverse ctermfg=darkmagenta") }
   449→  augroup vimrc_appearances
   450→    autocmd!
   451→    autocmd ColorScheme * call call( s:HighlightZenkakuSpace, [] )
   452→    autocmd VimEnter,WinEnter,BufRead * let w:m1=matchadd('ZenkakuSpace', '　')
   453→  augroup END
   454→  call call( s:HighlightZenkakuSpace, [] )
   455→endif
   456→
   457→highlight HighlightedyankRegion cterm=reverse gui=reverse
   458→
   459→"-----------------
   460→" Auto Commands
   461→"-----------------
   462→augroup vimrc
   463→  autocmd!
   464→  " plugin settings
   465→  autocmd BufReadPost * silent! DoShowMarks
   466→  " [lightline.vimとvim-anzuで検索ヒット数を表示する - Qiita](https://qiita.com/shiena/items/f53959d62085b7980cb5)
   467→  " autocmd CursorHold,CursorHoldI,WinLeave,TabLeave * call anzu#clear_search_status()
   468→
   469→  " [vaffle.vim から netrw にお試しで移行してみた - bamch0h’s diary](https://bamch0h.hatenablog.com/entry/2019/06/24/004104)
   470→  " autocmd FileType netrw nnoremap <buffer> h -
   471→  " autocmd FileType netrw nnoremap <buffer> l <CR>
   472→  " autocmd FileType netrw nnoremap <buffer> . gh
   473→
   474→  " [close vista window automatically when it's the last window open](https://github.com/liuchengxu/vista.vim/issues/108)
   475→  " autocmd BufEnter * if winnr("$") == 1 && vista#sidebar#IsOpen() | execute "normal! :q!\<CR>" | endif
   476→
   477→  " autocmd BufWritePost $MYVIMRC source $MYVIMRC | echo 'vimrc is reloaded.'
   478→
   479→  " 端末のバッファの名前を実行中プロセスを含むものに変更 https://qiita.com/acomagu/items/5f10ce7bcb2fcfc9732f
   480→  autocmd BufLeave * if exists('b:term_title') && exists('b:terminal_job_pid') | execute ":file term" . b:terminal_job_pid . "/" . b:term_title
   481→
   482→  " file type settings
   483→  autocmd BufNewFile,BufRead .env* set filetype=env
   484→  autocmd BufNewFile,BufRead git-__* set filetype=bash
   485→  autocmd BufNewFile,BufRead [^.]*shrc set filetype=bash
   486→  autocmd BufNewFile,BufRead .bashrc set filetype=bash
   487→  autocmd BufNewFile,BufRead *.py setlocal tabstop=4 softtabstop=4 shiftwidth=4
   488→  autocmd BufNewFile,BufRead *.go setlocal tabstop=4 softtabstop=4 shiftwidth=4
   489→  autocmd BufNewFile,BufRead *.java setlocal tabstop=4 softtabstop=4 shiftwidth=4
   490→
   491→  " " F4で現在のファイルを実行 https://qiita.com/i47_rozary/items/e02bd3b790a2d909ea9f
   492→  " autocmd FileType go noremap <Space>n :!go run %:p<CR>
   493→  " autocmd FileType javascript noremap <Space>n :!deno %:p<CR>
   494→  " autocmd FileType ruby noremap <Space>n :!ruby %:p<CR>
   495→  " autocmd FileType sh noremap <Space>n :!sh %:p<CR>
   496→
   497→  " [vim-quickrun シンプルかつまともに使える設定 - Qiita](https://qiita.com/uplus_e10/items/2a75fbe3d80063eb9c18)
   498→  " autocmd FileType qf nnoremap <silent><buffer>q :quit<CR>
   499→
   500→  " autocmd BufNewFile,BufRead *.md,*.json nnoremap <Space>p :<C-u>w<CR>:DenoFmt<CR>
   501→
   502→  " [NeovimのTerminalモードをちょっと使いやすくする](https://zenn.dev/ryo_kawamata/articles/improve-neovmi-terminal)
   503→  autocmd TermOpen * startinsert
   504→
   505→  " 前回終了位置に移動
   506→  autocmd BufReadPost * if line("'\"") > 0 && line("'\"") <= line('$') | execute 'normal g`"' | endif
   507→  autocmd BufReadPost * delmarks!
   508→
   509→  " [vim-jp » Hack #202: 自動的にディレクトリを作成する](https://vim-jp.org/vim-users-jp/2011/02/20/Hack-202.html)
   510→  autocmd BufWritePre * call s:auto_mkdir(expand('<afile>:p:h'), v:cmdbang)
   511→  function! s:auto_mkdir(dir, force)
   512→    if !isdirectory(a:dir) && (a:force ||
   513→          \    input(printf('"%s" does not exist. Create? [y/N]', a:dir)) =~? '^y\%[es]$')
   514→      call mkdir(iconv(a:dir, &encoding, &termencoding), 'p')
   515→    endif
   516→  endfunction
   517→
   518→augroup END

content.content:
# Flake Overview

This is a **Nix flake** for a Go project with development tooling and code quality checks.

## Main Build Output
The flake builds a default package by calling `pkgs.callPackage ./. { }`, which means the actual build definition is in the repository's default.nix file (not shown here).

## Development Dependencies
The development shell includes:
- **Go** compiler and tools
- **goreleaser** for building and releasing
- **gotools** for additional Go utilities

## Code Quality & Formatting Tools
The flake integrates multiple formatters and linters:
- **nixfmt** (with strict mode) for Nix code
- **gofmt, gofumpt, goimports, golines** for Go formatting
- **keep-sorted** for maintaining sorted lists
- **pinact** and **typos** for additional checks
- **actionlint** for GitHub Actions validation

## Additional Features
- Multi-platform support (x86_64/aarch64 on Linux and macOS)
- Pre-commit hooks that enforce treefmt and actionlint checks
- Git hooks integration via the cachix/git-hooks.nix module

The project appears to be a Go utility with strong emphasis on code consistency and automated quality checks.

content.content:
# Cage: Security Sandbox CLI Tool

## What It Does

Cage is a cross-platform CLI tool that executes commands within a restricted sandbox environment. As described in the documentation, it "executes commands with restricted file system write access while maintaining full read permissions."

## How It Works

The tool uses different underlying technologies depending on your operating system:

- **Linux**: Leverages Landlock LSM (requires kernel 5.13+) to enforce restrictions at the kernel level
- **macOS**: Employs `sandbox-exec` with custom sandbox profiles to control access

Both approaches share the same philosophy: blocking write operations by default while permitting reads and executions across the entire filesystem.

## Main Features

The key capabilities include:

1. **Write-only restrictions** - Commands retain read access everywhere but cannot write unless explicitly allowed
2. **Selective permissions** - The `-allow` flag grants write access to specific paths; multiple paths can be specified
3. **Special permissions** - Flags like `-allow-keychain` (macOS) and `-allow-git` enable access to specific system resources
4. **Preset configurations** - Reusable settings for common tools (npm, cargo, etc.)
5. **Debug mode** - The `-allow-all` flag disables all restrictions for troubleshooting
6. **Process replacement** - Uses `syscall.Exec` to prevent sandbox bypass techniques

## Configuration Options

Users can configure cage through:

- **Command-line flags** for direct control
- **YAML configuration files** stored in platform-specific directories (Linux: `~/.config/cage/`, macOS: `~/Library/Application Support/cage/`)
- **Auto-presets** that automatically apply configurations based on the executed command

The configuration system supports path evaluation, symlink resolution, and preset composition for flexible security policies.

content.text:
## Summary: Cage Tool

**Cage** is a cross-platform CLI security sandbox tool that executes commands within a restricted environment. Here's what it does:

### Core Purpose
Executes commands with restricted **write** access while maintaining **full read permissions** across the filesystem. It's a security boundary tool that prevents unintended file modifications while letting processes read and execute freely.

### How It Works

**Linux**: Uses Landlock LSM (kernel 5.13+) to enforce restrictions at the kernel level
**macOS**: Uses `sandbox-exec` with custom sandbox profiles

### Key Features

1. **Write-only restrictions** - Blocks writes by default but allows reads everywhere
2. **Selective allowlisting** - The `-allow` flag grants write access to specific paths
3. **Special permissions** - Flags like `-allow-keychain` (macOS) and `-allow-git` enable specific system resources
4. **Preset configurations** - Pre-built settings for common tools (npm, cargo, etc.)
5. **Debug mode** - `-allow-all` flag to disable restrictions for troubleshooting
6. **Process replacement** - Uses `syscall.Exec` to prevent sandbox bypass

### Configuration

Users configure cage via:
- **Command-line flags** for direct control
- **YAML files** in platform-specific directories:
  - Linux: `~/.config/cage/`
  - macOS: `~/Library/Application Support/cage/`
- **Auto-presets** that apply configurations based on the executed command

The project is written in **Go** with strong quality enforcement (nixfmt, gofmt, gofumpt, goimports, pre-commit hooks, etc.).

content.content:
# Cage: Security Sandbox CLI Tool

## Overview

Cage is a cross-platform security sandbox that "executes commands with restricted file system write access while maintaining full read permissions." It's designed for safely running untrusted code, limiting filesystem modifications during development, analyzing scripts without system changes, and processing sensitive data with controlled outputs.

## Key Features

The tool provides:
- **Write-only restriction**: Commands can read files but cannot write unless explicitly allowed
- **Cross-platform support**: Works on Linux (kernel 5.13+) and macOS
- **Flexible permissions**: Grant write access to specific paths using `-allow` flags
- **Debug mode**: Disable restrictions with `-allow-all`
- **Transparent execution**: Uses `syscall.Exec` to replace the process

## Installation

Users can install via Homebrew (macOS), `go install`, or from source by cloning the repository.

## Basic Usage

The syntax is: `cage [flags] <command> [args...]`

### Key Flags

- `-allow <path>`: Grant write access to a specific path (repeatable)
- `-allow-keychain`: Allow macOS keychain writes
- `-allow-git`: Enable git operations in worktrees
- `-allow-all`: Disable all restrictions
- `-preset <name>`: Use predefined preset configuration
- `-list-presets`: Display available presets
- `-config <path>`: Specify custom configuration file

## YAML Configuration Format

Configuration files (searched in `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/cage/` or platform defaults) use YAML structure. The format supports:

```yaml
presets:
  preset-name:
    allow:
      - "/path/one"
      - "/path/two"
      - path: "/symlinked/path"
        eval-symlinks: true
    allow-git: boolean
    allow-keychain: boolean

auto-presets:
  - command: command-name
    presets: [preset1, preset2]
  - command-pattern: "^(cmd1|cmd2)$"
    presets: [preset3]
```

The `eval-symlinks` option resolves symlinks to actual paths—particularly useful on macOS where `/tmp` links to `/private/tmp`.

## Platform Implementation

- **Linux**: Uses Landlock LSM (kernel 5.13+) to grant read/execute access filesystem-wide, with writes restricted to `/dev/null` and allowed paths
- **macOS**: Employs `sandbox-exec` with custom profiles denying all writes except to allowed paths
- **Other platforms**: Return errors indicating unsupported sandboxing

content.content:
# Cage: Security Sandbox CLI Tool

## What Is Cage?

Cage is a command-line utility designed to run potentially untrusted commands with restricted file system write access. As stated in the documentation, it's "a cross-platform security sandbox CLI tool that executes commands with restricted file system write access while maintaining full read permissions."

The tool operates on Linux (kernel 5.13+) and macOS, using platform-specific sandboxing mechanisms—Landlock LSM on Linux and sandbox-exec profiles on macOS.

## Key Capabilities

The core functionality centers on write restrictions. Users can execute commands that retain full read and execute permissions while blocking write operations to all paths except those explicitly permitted via `-allow` flags.

Notable features include:
- **Flexible permissions**: Multiple `-allow` flags enable granular control over writable paths
- **Keychain access** (macOS): The `-allow-keychain` flag grants access to system credentials
- **Git operations**: The `-allow-git` flag supports worktree environments
- **Debug mode**: `-allow-all` disables all sandbox restrictions
- **Presets**: Predefined configurations reduce repetitive flag usage

## Installation Methods

**Homebrew** (macOS):
```bash
brew install --cask Warashi/tap/cage --no-quarantine
```

**Go installation**:
```bash
go install github.com/Warashi/cage@latest
```

**From source**:
```bash
git clone https://github.com/Warashi/cage
cd cage && go build
```

## Practical Usage Examples

### Basic Execution with Restrictions
```bash
cage python suspicious_script.py
```
This runs the Python script with read-only file system access.

### Controlled Output Directories
```bash
cage -allow ./output -- ./process_data.sh /sensitive/data
```
The script can read sensitive data but write only to the output folder.

### Development Workflows
```bash
cage -allow ./build -allow ./dist -- npm run build
```
Compilation output gets restricted to specified directories.

### Multi-Tool Projects
```bash
cage -preset npm npm install
cage -preset cargo cargo build
```
Presets automatically apply commonly needed permissions.

### Git Operations
```bash
cage -allow-git -allow . -- git commit -m "Update files"
```
The `-allow-git` flag enables repository management.

## Configuration System

Users can create YAML configuration files defining reusable presets. The system searches for configs in platform-specific locations:
- **Linux**: `$HOME/.config/cage/`
- **macOS**: `$HOME/Library/Application Support/cage/`

Preset definitions specify allowed paths and feature flags:

```yaml
presets:
  npm:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "$HOME/.npm"
      - "$HOME/.cache/npm"
```

The documentation notes that "allow fields in presets support both simple string paths and objects with an `eval-symlinks` option," which automatically resolves symbolic links to actual paths—particularly useful since macOS `/tmp` links to `/private/tmp`.

## Auto-Presets Feature

Configuration files can define automatic preset application based on executed commands:

```yaml
auto-presets:
  - command: npm
    presets:
      - npm
  - command-pattern: ^(npm|yarn)$
    presets:
      - nodejs-tools
```

This eliminates repetitive flag usage for frequently executed commands.

## Security Model

The tool maintains a strict security policy: file reads and execution remain unrestricted by default, while write operations are universally blocked unless explicitly allowed. Network access and process creation face no restrictions—the focus remains strictly on file system modifications.

## Environment Integration

Cage sets the `IN_CAGE=1` environment variable within sandboxed processes, allowing programs to detect execution within the sandbox. This proves particularly useful for Homebrew compatibility on macOS, where the standard shellenv evaluation can fail under sandbox restrictions.

## Limitations

The documentation specifies that "sandboxing is only implemented for Linux and macOS," with Linux requiring Landlock support (kernel 5.13+). Network and process execution restrictions remain unimplemented, and read operations cannot be restricted—the tool focuses exclusively on preventing unwanted file modifications.

## Use Cases

Cage serves multiple purposes: restricting build outputs during development, safely analyzing potentially malicious scripts, processing sensitive data with controlled output locations, and supporting LLM-based code agents that require sandboxed execution environments.

# Go Config Structure and YAML Parsing Logic

## Core Data Structures

The configuration system defines several interconnected types:

**Primary Config**: The root `Config` struct contains two main fields:
- `Presets`: A map of named preset configurations
- `AutoPresets`: A slice of rules for automatic preset application

**Preset Definition**: Each `Preset` specifies access permissions:
- `Allow`: Paths that are accessible (with optional symlink resolution)
- `AllowKeychain`: Boolean for keychain access
- `AllowGit`: Boolean for git repository access

**Path Configuration**: The `AllowPath` type stores individual paths with metadata for symlink evaluation.

**Auto-Preset Rules**: The `AutoPresetRule` type matches commands via exact name or regex pattern, then applies corresponding presets.

## YAML Parsing Implementation

The system uses custom unmarshaling to handle flexible input formats. The `AllowPath` field demonstrates this with a custom `UnmarshalYAML` method that accepts either:
- A simple string value (converted to an AllowPath with default settings)
- A structured map with explicit path and symlink evaluation flags

The parsing flow:
1. Config files are located via `XDG_CONFIG_HOME` environment variable or system config directory
2. Files named `presets.yaml` or `presets.yml` are searched
3. YAML content is unmarshaled into the Config struct
4. Methods like `GetPreset()` and `GetAutoPresets()` provide runtime access

The `ProcessPreset()` method performs post-parsing transformations, expanding environment variables and resolving symlinks as needed.

content.content:
# Go Struct Definitions from config.go

Based on the GitHub repository content, here are all the struct definitions and types:

## Struct Definitions

**Config**
```go
type Config struct {
    Presets map[string]Preset `yaml:"presets"`
    AutoPresets []AutoPresetRule `yaml:"auto-presets"`
}
```

**Preset**
```go
type Preset struct {
    Allow []AllowPath `yaml:"allow"`
    AllowKeychain bool `yaml:"allow-keychain"`
    AllowGit bool `yaml:"allow-git"`
}
```

**AllowPath**
```go
type AllowPath struct {
    Path string `yaml:"path"`
    EvalSymLinks bool `yaml:"eval-symlinks,omitempty"`
}
```

**AutoPresetRule**
```go
type AutoPresetRule struct {
    Command string `yaml:"command,omitempty"`
    CommandPattern string `yaml:"command-pattern,omitempty"`
    Presets []string `yaml:"presets"`
}
```

## Key Methods

- `UnmarshalYAML()` - Custom unmarshaling for AllowPath
- `GetPreset()` - Retrieves a preset by name
- `ListPresets()` - Returns all preset names
- `GetAutoPresets()` - Matches commands against rules
- `ProcessPreset()` - Expands environment variables and resolves symlinks

The configuration system supports environment variable expansion, symlink resolution, and regex-based command pattern matching.

content.content:
# Cage Repository Overview

**Cage** is a cross-platform security sandbox CLI tool that executes commands with restricted file system write access while maintaining full read permissions.

## Key Files & Structure

Based on the repository contents:

**Core Implementation Files:**
- `sandbox.go`, `sandbox_darwin.go`, `sandbox_linux.go`, `sandbox_other.go` - Platform-specific sandbox implementations
- `dryrun.go` and platform variants - Dry-run/test functionality
- `config.go` - Configuration management
- `main.go` - Entry point

**Configuration & Examples:**
- `examples/` directory - Contains usage examples
- `.goreleaser.yaml` - Release configuration
- Nix support via `flake.nix`, `default.nix`, and `.tagpr`

**Testing:**
- `test_e2e.sh` - End-to-end test suite
- `*_test.go` files - Unit tests

## Preset System

The tool supports YAML-based presets for common development workflows:

**Built-in Presets Include:**
- `npm` - Node.js development (allows current directory, npm cache)
- `cargo` - Rust development (allows cargo/rustup directories)
- `git-enabled` - Git operations with SSH access
- `claude-code` - Claude Code agent configuration

**Configuration Location:**
Users can place preset files at `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/cage/presets.yaml` (Linux) or platform-specific config directories.

**Auto-Presets Feature:**
The system can automatically apply presets based on command patterns, enabling commands like `cage claude help` to inherit appropriate permissions automatically.

# Complete presets.yaml File

Here's the full configuration shown in the source:

```yaml
presets:
  npm:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "$HOME/.npm"
      - "$HOME/.cache/npm"
      - "$HOME/.npmrc"
  
  cargo:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "$HOME/.cargo"
      - "$HOME/.rustup"
      - "$HOME/.cache/sccache"
  
  pip:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "$HOME/.cache/pip"
      - "$HOME/.local"
      - "$HOME/Library/Caches/pip"
  
  go:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "$HOME/go"
      - "$HOME/.cache/go-build"
  
  node:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "$HOME/.npm"
      - "$HOME/.cache/npm"
      - "$HOME/.npmrc"
      - "node_modules"
  
  ruby:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "$HOME/.gem"
      - "$HOME/.bundle"
      - "$HOME/.rbenv"
      - "$HOME/.rvm"
  
  python:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "$HOME/.pyenv"
      - "$HOME/.cache/pip"
      - "$HOME/.local"
      - "$HOME/.virtualenvs"
      - "venv"
      - ".venv"
  
  homebrew:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "/usr/local/Homebrew"
      - "/opt/homebrew"
      - "$HOME/Library/Caches/Homebrew"
      - "$HOME/Library/Logs/Homebrew"

  claude-code:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "/tmp"
      - "/private/tmp"
      - "/dev/tty"
      - "$HOME/.claude"
      - "$HOME/.claude.json"
      - "$HOME/.claude.json.backup"
      - "$HOME/.claude.json.lock"
      - "$HOME/.claude.lock"
    allow-keychain: true
    allow-git: true
```

This file defines permitted filesystem access paths for various package managers and development tools integrated with Claude Code.

content.content:
# Configuration Parsing: Edge Cases & Supported Formats

## Core Features Tested

**YAML Loading:**
- Valid config parsing with nested preset structures
- Missing file handling (returns empty config gracefully)
- Invalid syntax detection and error reporting

**Preset Management:**
- Exact preset retrieval via `GetPreset()`
- Listing all available presets
- Non-existent preset handling

## Path Format Support

The test suite validates two `AllowPath` representations:

1. **String Format:** Simple path as scalar value
   ```yaml
   allow:
     - "/tmp/test"
   ```

2. **Object Format:** Structured with optional `eval-symlinks` flag
   ```yaml
   allow:
     - path: "/var"
       eval-symlinks: true
   ```

The implementation rejects unsupported types (numbers, arrays) with clear error messages.

## Environment & Substitution Handling

**Supported:**
- Variable expansion: `$HOME`, `${TEST_VAR}` formats both work
- Preserves special characters and spaces in paths
- Default behavior when variables are undefined

**Not Supported:**
- Command substitution like `$(echo /tmp)` remains literal
- This intentional limitation prevents shell injection risks

## Advanced Features

**Auto-Preset Rules:**
- Exact command matching: `command: "claude"`
- Regex pattern matching: `command-pattern: "^(npm|npx|yarn)$"`
- Path extraction (handles `/usr/bin/claude` → `claude`)

**Symlink Handling:**
Tests confirm `eval-symlinks: true` resolves symbolic links to their targets, while `false` preserves the original path. Non-existent symlinks fall back to the original path gracefully.

**Optional Flags:**
- `allow-keychain: true` enables system keychain access
- `allow-git: true` preserves git directory configuration

content.text:
Perfect! Now I have all the information needed. Let me compile a comprehensive report:

## Cage YAML Configuration Format - Complete Reference

Based on my exploration of both the **Warashi/cage** repository and the **kawarimidoll/dotfiles** configuration, here's the complete cage configuration specification:

### Configuration File Location

- **Linux**: `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/cage/` (defaults to `~/.config/cage/`)
- **macOS**: `$HOME/Library/Application Support/cage/`
- **File names**: `presets.yaml` or `presets.yml`

### Core YAML Structure

```yaml
presets:
  preset-name:
    allow:
      - "/path/one"
      - "/path/two"
      - path: "/symlinked/path"
        eval-symlinks: true
    allow-git: boolean
    allow-keychain: boolean

auto-presets:
  - command: command-name
    presets:
      - preset1
      - preset2
  - command-pattern: "^(cmd1|cmd2)$"
    presets:
      - preset3
```

### Preset Definition Details

Each preset can contain:

1. **`allow` (array of paths)**:
   - **String format**: Simple path `"/path/to/directory"`
   - **Object format**: With symlink resolution
     ```yaml
     path: "/path/to/directory"
     eval-symlinks: true
     ```
   - Supports environment variables: `$HOME`, `$XDG_CONFIG_DIR`, `${VAR_NAME}`
   - Variables are expanded at parse time

2. **`allow-git` (boolean, optional)**:
   - Enables git operations in worktrees
   - Allows repository configuration and commits

3. **`allow-keychain` (boolean, optional)**:
   - macOS-only feature
   - Grants access to system keychain credentials

### Auto-Presets Feature

Automatically apply presets based on command invocation:

```yaml
auto-presets:
  - command: npm              # Exact command match
    presets:
      - base
      - npm
  
  - command-pattern: "^(npm|npx|yarn)$"  # Regex pattern match
    presets:
      - nodejs-tools
```

Key behaviors:
- Command pattern matching uses regex
- Handles full paths by extracting basename (`/usr/bin/claude` → `claude`)
- First matching rule applies

### Go Struct Definitions

```go
type Config struct {
    Presets     map[string]Preset   `yaml:"presets"`
    AutoPresets []AutoPresetRule    `yaml:"auto-presets"`
}

type Preset struct {
    Allow         []AllowPath `yaml:"allow"`
    AllowKeychain bool       `yaml:"allow-keychain"`
    AllowGit      bool       `yaml:"allow-git"`
}

type AllowPath struct {
    Path          string `yaml:"path"`
    EvalSymLinks  bool   `yaml:"eval-symlinks,omitempty"`
}

type AutoPresetRule struct {
    Command        string   `yaml:"command,omitempty"`
    CommandPattern string   `yaml:"command-pattern,omitempty"`
    Presets        []string `yaml:"presets"`
}
```

### Example Configuration: kawarimidoll/dotfiles

**File**: `/Users/yuta/ghq/github.com/kawarimidoll/dotfiles/.config/cage/presets.yml`

```yaml
presets:
  base:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "$XDG_CACHE_HOME"
      - "$XDG_DATA_HOME"
      - "/private/tmp"       # macOS tmp directory
      - "/var/folders"       # macOS mktemp
      - "/Library/Caches"    # macOS app caches
      - "$HOME/Library/Caches"

  npm:
    allow:
      - "$HOME/.npm"
      - "$HOME/.npmrc"

  git-enabled:
    allow-git: true
    allow-keychain: true    # macOS only

  claude-code:
    allow:
      - "$CLAUDE_CONFIG_DIR"
      - "$HOME/.serena"
      - "$HOME/.agent-browser"
      - "$HOME/.browser-profile"
      - "$HOME/.codex"
      - ".serena"

  happy:
    allow:
      - "$HOME/.happy"

auto-presets:
  - command: claude
    presets:
      - base
      - git-enabled
      - npm
      - claude-code

  - command: happy
    presets:
      - base
      - git-enabled
      - npm
      - claude-code
      - happy

  - command: git
    presets:
      - base
      - git-enabled
```

### Canonical Example Presets (from Warashi/cage repo)

```yaml
presets:
  npm:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "$HOME/.npm"
      - "$HOME/.cache/npm"
      - "$HOME/.npmrc"

  cargo:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "$HOME/.cargo"
      - "$HOME/.rustup"
      - "$HOME/.cache/sccache"

  python:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "$HOME/.pyenv"
      - "$HOME/.cache/pip"
      - "$HOME/.local"
      - "$HOME/.virtualenvs"
      - "venv"
      - ".venv"

  claude-code:
    allow:
      - "."
      - "/tmp"
      - "/private/tmp"
      - "/dev/tty"
      - "$HOME/.claude"
      - "$HOME/.claude.json"
      - "$HOME/.claude.json.backup"
      - "$HOME/.claude.json.lock"
      - "$HOME/.claude.lock"
    allow-keychain: true
    allow-git: true
```

### Flake Integration (kawarimidoll/dotfiles)

**File**: `/Users/yuta/ghq/github.com/kawarimidoll/dotfiles/flake.nix` (lines 46-52)

```nix
cage = {
  url = "github:Warashi/cage";
  inputs.nixpkgs.follows = "nixpkgs";
  inputs.git-hooks.follows = "git-hooks";
  inputs.flake-parts.follows = "flake-parts";
  inputs.treefmt-nix.follows = "treefmt-nix";
};
```

**Home-Manager Integration**:
Cage is imported as a package and made available in the environment:
```nix
cage = inputs.cage.packages.${system}.default;
```

### Configuration Features

1. **Environment Variable Expansion**:
   - `$HOME` → user home directory
   - `${VAR_NAME}` → environment variable
   - Undefined variables preserve original text

2. **Symlink Resolution**:
   - `eval-symlinks: true` resolves symbolic links to actual paths
   - Useful for macOS where `/tmp` → `/private/tmp`
   - Default (`false`) preserves original path

3. **Special Features**:
   - `allow-git`: Enables git worktree operations
   - `allow-keychain`: macOS credential access
   - `IN_CAGE=1`: Environment variable set in sandboxed process for detection

### Sandbox Behavior

- **Write restrictions**: All paths blocked for writing except those in `allow` list
- **Read/Execute**: Unrestricted across entire filesystem
- **Network**: Unrestricted
- **Process creation**: Unrestricted
- **Implementation**:
  - Linux: Landlock LSM (kernel 5.13+)
  - macOS: sandbox-exec profiles
  - Other platforms: Errors returned

This makes cage ideal for safely running LLM agents (like Claude Code), build tools, and untrusted scripts while controlling where they can write files.

    claude-code

    opencode
    vibe-kanban
    cursor-agent
    # Version Control
    git
    git-wt
    git-lfs
    git-filter-repo
    lazygit
    jujutsu
    jj-desc
    entire

    # Development Tools
    repiq
    nil
    nix-init
    ni

    # Google Suite
    gogcli

    # CLI Utilities
    curl
    wget
    aria2
    xh
    ripgrep
    fzf
    peco
    jq
    jnv
    tokei
    cloc

    lsd

    halloy
    obsidian

    # Network Tools
    tunnelto
    speedtest-cli
    bandwhich
    nmap
    dnsutils

    # Misc
    sl
    fastfetch
  ];
}

1→#!/usr/bin/env zsh
     2→
     3→# ========================================
     4→# Aliases
     5→# ========================================
     6→
     7→# rebuild - unified via flake apps
     8→alias rebuild="nix run ~/ghq/github.com/yutakobayashidev/dotnix#switch && source ~/.zshrc"
     9→
    10→# Platform-specific aliases
    11→if [[ "$(uname)" == "Darwin" ]]; then
    12→  alias cpd="pwd | pbcopy"
    13→else
    14→  alias cpd="pwd | wl-copy"
    15→fi
    16→
    17→# AI tools
    18→alias cl="claude"
    19→alias cld="claude --dangerously-skip-permissions"
    20→alias cldc="claude --dangerously-skip-permissions --continue"

1→#!/usr/bin/env zsh
     2→
     3→# ========================================
     4→# Main zsh configuration
     5→# ========================================
     6→
     7→# "do" alias breaks for/do/done keywords on re-source
     8→unalias do 2>/dev/null
     9→
    10→# home-manager session variables
    11→HM_SESSION_VARS="$HOME/.local/state/home-manager/gcroots/current-home/home-path/etc/profile.d/hm-session-vars.sh"
    12→if [ -f "$HM_SESSION_VARS" ]; then
    13→  . "$HM_SESSION_VARS"
    14→fi
    15→
    16→# Enable completion
    17→autoload -Uz compinit && compinit
    18→
    19→# git-wt
    20→eval "$(git wt --init zsh)"
    21→
    22→# ========================================
    23→# Load config files
    24→# ========================================
    25→
    26→# oh-my-zsh configuration (must be loaded first)
    27→source ~/.config/zsh/config/oh-my-zsh.zsh
    28→
    29→# zsh plugins
    30→source ~/.zsh/plugins/zsh-autosuggestions/zsh-autosuggestions.zsh
    31→source ~/.zsh/plugins/zsh-syntax-highlighting/zsh-syntax-highlighting.zsh
    32→source ~/.zsh/plugins/fzf-tab/fzf-tab.plugin.zsh
    33→
    34→# ========================================
    35→# Load functions
    36→# ========================================
    37→
    38→for func in ~/.config/zsh/functions/*.zsh; do
    39→  source "$func"
    40→done
    41→
    42→# aliases (must be after functions loop — "do" alias breaks for/do/done)
    43→source ~/.config/zsh/config/aliases.zsh
    44→
    45→# zoxide (must be after oh-my-zsh to avoid cd being overwritten)
    46→eval "$(zoxide init zsh --cmd cd)"
    47→
    48→# direnv (must be last to avoid spurious unloading messages)
    49→eval "$(direnv hook zsh)"
    50→

Perfect! Now I have all the information I need. Let me compile the findings:

## Summary

I found the zsh alias definitions and how dotfiles are managed in this project. Here are the findings:

### 1. Aliases File Location
**File**: `/Users/yuta/ghq/github.com/yutakobayashidev/dotnix/zsh/config/aliases.zsh`

**Full Contents**:
```zsh
#!/usr/bin/env zsh

# ========================================
# Aliases
# ========================================

# rebuild - unified via flake apps
alias rebuild="nix run ~/ghq/github.com/yutakobayashidev/dotnix#switch && source ~/.zshrc"

# Platform-specific aliases
if [[ "$(uname)" == "Darwin" ]]; then
  alias cpd="pwd | pbcopy"
else
  alias cpd="pwd | wl-copy"
fi

# AI tools
alias cl="claude"
alias cld="claude --dangerously-skip-permissions"
alias cldc="claude --dangerously-skip-permissions --continue"
alias clh="claude --dangerously-skip-permissions --model haiku"
alias clo="claude --dangerously-skip-permissions --model opus"
alias cls="claude --dangerously-skip-permissions --model sonnet"
alias oc="opencode"
alias cx="codex"
alias ca="cursor-agent"
alias ct="continues"

# Docker
alias do="docker container"
alias dop="docker container ps"
alias dob="docker container build"
alias dor="docker container run --rm"
alias dox="docker container exec -it"

# Docker Compose
alias dc="docker compose"
alias dcu="docker compose up"
alias dcub="docker compose up --build"
alias dcd="docker compose down"
alias dcr="docker compose restart"

# Nix
alias ns="nix-shell"
alias ngc="nix-collect-garbage"
nrn() { nix run "nixpkgs#$1" "${@:2}"; }
alias ashiba="nfi github:yutakobayashidev/ashiba"
alias ndt="nfi github:the-nix-way/dev-templates"

# Security
scorecard() { GITHUB_AUTH_TOKEN="$(gh auth token)" command scorecard "$@"; }

alias p="pnpm"
alias ls="lsd -1A"
alias ll="lsd -l"
alias la="lsd -la"
alias lt="lsd --tree"
alias cat="bat"
alias gg="ghq get"
alias browse-pr="gh pr view --web"
alias isv='gh issue list | fzf-tmux --prompt "issue preview>" --preview "echo {} | awk '\''{print \$1}'\'' | xargs gh issue view -p" | xargs gh issue view'
alias prv='gh pr list | fzf-tmux --prompt "pr preview>" --preview "echo {} | awk '\''{print \$1}'\'' | xargs gh pr view -p" | xargs gh pr view'
alias browse="gh repo view --web"
alias brc='echo "$(gh repo view --json url --jq .url)/commit/$(git rev-parse HEAD)"'
alias gundo="git reset --soft HEAD~1"
alias grepush="git recommit && git push -f"
alias gsp="git stash && git pull && git stash pop"
alias gpgp="git pull && git push"
alias gpu="git pull"
alias rmswap="find . -type f -name \"*.swp\" -delete && find . -type f -name \".*.swp\" -delete"
```

**Note on CLAUDE.md**: The CLAUDE.md mentions `yolo` alias but it's **not defined in aliases.zsh**. The CLAUDE.md says it should map to `claude --dangerously-skip-permissions`, but the actual file only defines `cld` for that (line 19).

### 2. Dotfiles Management via dotfiles.nix
**File**: `/Users/yuta/ghq/github.com/yutakobayashidev/dotnix/nix/modules/home/dotfiles.nix`

**Full Contents**:
```nix
{
  lib,
  pkgs,
  config,
  helpers,
  dotfilesDir,
  ...
}:

let
  inherit (config.home) homeDirectory;
  inherit (config.xdg) configHome;
in
{
  home.activation.linkDotfiles = lib.hm.dag.entryAfter [ "linkGeneration" ] ''
    ${helpers.activation.mkLinkForce}

    # zsh
    link_force "${dotfilesDir}/zshenv" "${homeDirectory}/.zshenv"
    link_force "${dotfilesDir}/zsh/zshrc" "${homeDirectory}/.zshrc"
    link_force "${dotfilesDir}/zsh" "${configHome}/zsh"

    # Karabiner Elements configuration (macOS only)
    # Restart Karabiner console user server before updating config to prevent keyboard freeze
    # The daemon can enter an inconsistent state if config changes while running
    if [[ "$(uname)" == "Darwin" ]]; then
      if /bin/launchctl list | ${pkgs.gnugrep}/bin/grep -q "org.pqrs.service.agent.karabiner_console_user_server"; then
        echo "Restarting Karabiner console user server before config update..."
        /bin/launchctl kickstart -k gui/$(/usr/bin/id -u)/org.pqrs.service.agent.karabiner_console_user_server 2>/dev/null || true
        sleep 2
      fi
      link_force "${dotfilesDir}/karabiner" "${configHome}/karabiner"
    fi
  '';
}
```

### 3. How dotfilesDir is Configured

The `dotfilesDir` is defined in each host configuration (not globally). Example from macOS host:

**File**: `/Users/yuta/ghq/github.com/yutakobayashidev/dotnix/nix/hosts/M2-MacBook-Air/default.nix` (lines 12-13)

```nix
helpers = import ../../modules/lib/helpers { lib = nixpkgs.lib; };
dotfilesDir = "/Users/yuta/ghq/github.com/yutakobayashidev/dotnix";
```

Then it's passed to home-manager as an extra special argument (lines 37-44):
```nix
extraSpecialArgs = {
  inherit
    inputs
    helpers
    dotfilesDir
    local-skills
    ;
};
```

### Key Points

1. **Claude aliases exist**: `cl`, `cld`, `cldc`, `clh`, `clo`, `cls` are defined, but the `yolo` alias mentioned in CLAUDE.md is **missing** from the aliases.zsh file.

2. **Dotfiles linking**: The project uses home-manager's `home.activation.linkDotfiles` hook to symlink dotfiles from the repository to the actual configuration locations (e.g., `~/.config/zsh`, `~/.zshrc`).

3. **Path-specific configuration**: Each host (macOS, NixOS) defines its own absolute `dotfilesDir` path in its host configuration file, then passes it through home-manager's `extraSpecialArgs`.

4. **zsh configuration flow**: zshrc sources config files from `~/.config/zsh/`, which is symlinked by dotfiles.nix to point to the repository's zsh directory.

```zsh
alias p="pnpm"
alias ls="lsd -1A"
alias ll="lsd -l"
alias la="lsd -la"
alias lt="lsd --tree"
alias cat="bat"
alias gg="ghq get"
alias browse-pr="gh pr view --web"
alias isv='gh issue list | fzf-tmux --prompt "issue preview>" --preview "echo {} | awk '\''{print \$1}'\'' | xargs gh issue view -p" | xargs gh issue view'
alias prv='gh pr list | fzf-tmux --prompt "pr preview>" --preview "echo {} | awk '\''{print \$1}'\'' | xargs gh pr view -p" | xargs gh pr view'
alias browse="gh repo view --web"
alias brc='echo "$(gh repo view --json url --jq .url)/commit/$(git rev-parse HEAD)"'
alias gundo="git reset --soft HEAD~1"
alias grepush="git recommit && git push -f"
alias gsp="git stash && git pull && git stash pop"
alias gpgp="git pull && git push"
alias gpu="git pull"
alias rmswap="find . -type f -name \"*.swp\" -delete && find . -type f -name \".*.swp\" -delete"
```

**Note on CLAUDE.md**: The CLAUDE.md mentions `yolo` alias but it's **not defined in aliases.zsh**. The CLAUDE.md says it should map to `claude --dangerously-skip-permissions`, but the actual file only defines `cld` for that (line 19).

### 2. Dotfiles Management via dotfiles.nix
**File**: `/Users/yuta/ghq/github.com/yutakobayashidev/dotnix/nix/modules/home/dotfiles.nix`

**Full Contents**:
```nix
{
  lib,
  pkgs,
  config,
  helpers,
  dotfilesDir,
  ...
}:

let
  inherit (config.home) homeDirectory;
  inherit (config.xdg) configHome;
in
{
  home.activation.linkDotfiles = lib.hm.dag.entryAfter [ "linkGeneration" ] ''
    ${helpers.activation.mkLinkForce}

    # zsh
    link_force "${dotfilesDir}/zshenv" "${homeDirectory}/.zshenv"
    link_force "${dotfilesDir}/zsh/zshrc" "${homeDirectory}/.zshrc"
    link_force "${dotfilesDir}/zsh" "${configHome}/zsh"

    # Karabiner Elements configuration (macOS only)
    # Restart Karabiner console user server before updating config to prevent keyboard freeze
    # The daemon can enter an inconsistent state if config changes while running
    if [[ "$(uname)" == "Darwin" ]]; then
      if /bin/launchctl list | ${pkgs.gnugrep}/bin/grep -q "org.pqrs.service.agent.karabiner_console_user_server"; then
        echo "Restarting Karabiner console user server before config update..."
        /bin/launchctl kickstart -k gui/$(/usr/bin/id -u)/org.pqrs.service.agent.karabiner_console_user_server 2>/dev/null || true
        sleep 2
      fi
      link_force "${dotfilesDir}/karabiner" "${configHome}/karabiner"
    fi
  '';
}
```

### 3. How dotfilesDir is Configured

The `dotfilesDir` is defined in each host configuration (not globally). Example from macOS host:

**File**: `/Users/yuta/ghq/github.com/yutakobayashidev/dotnix/nix/hosts/M2-MacBook-Air/default.nix` (lines 12-13)

```nix
helpers = import ../../modules/lib/helpers { lib = nixpkgs.lib; };
dotfilesDir = "/Users/yuta/ghq/github.com/yutakobayashidev/dotnix";
```

Then it's passed to home-manager as an extra special argument (lines 37-44):
```nix
extraSpecialArgs = {
  inherit
    inputs
    helpers
    dotfilesDir
    local-skills
    ;
};
```

### Key Points

1. **Claude aliases exist**: `cl`, `cld`, `cldc`, `clh`, `clo`, `cls` are defined, but the `yolo` alias mentioned in CLAUDE.md is **missing** from the aliases.zsh file.

2. **Dotfiles linking**: The project uses home-manager's `home.activation.linkDotfiles` hook to symlink dotfiles from the repository to the actual configuration locations (e.g., `~/.config/zsh`, `~/.zshrc`).

3. **Path-specific configuration**: Each host (macOS, NixOS) defines its own absolute `dotfilesDir` path in its host configuration file, then passes it through home-manager's `extraSpecialArgs`.

4. **zsh configuration flow**: zshrc sources config files from `~/.config/zsh/`, which is symlinked by dotfiles.nix to point to the repository's zsh directory.

# Flake Inputs Overview

Based on the flake.nix content provided, here are all the inputs this flake requires:

## Primary Inputs

1. **flake-parts** - `github:hercules-ci/flake-parts`
2. **nixpkgs** - `github:nixos/nixpkgs/nixpkgs-unstable`
3. **git-hooks** - `github:cachix/git-hooks.nix`
4. **treefmt-nix** - `github:numtide/treefmt-nix`

## Follows Directives Already Configured

The flake already implements these `follows` relationships:
- `git-hooks.inputs.nixpkgs` follows the main `nixpkgs`
- `treefmt-nix.inputs.nixpkgs` follows the main `nixpkgs`

## Setup Recommendation

If you're using this flake as a dependency in another project, you should add follows directives for `flake-parts`, `git-hooks`, and `treefmt-nix` to ensure they use your parent flake's nixpkgs version:

```nix
flake-parts.follows = "nixpkgs";
git-hooks.follows = "nixpkgs";
treefmt-nix.follows = "nixpkgs";
```

This maintains consistency across your dependency tree and prevents multiple nixpkgs instances.

file.content:
#!/usr/bin/env zsh

# ========================================
# Aliases
# ========================================

# rebuild - unified via flake apps
alias rebuild="nix run ~/ghq/github.com/yutakobayashidev/dotnix#switch && source ~/.zshrc"

# Platform-specific aliases
if [[ "$(uname)" == "Darwin" ]]; then
  alias cpd="pwd | pbcopy"
else
  alias cpd="pwd | wl-copy"
fi

# AI tools
alias cl="claude"
alias cld="claude --dangerously-skip-permissions"
alias cldc="claude --dangerously-skip-permissions --continue"
alias clh="claude --dangerously-skip-permissions --model haiku"
alias clo="claude --dangerously-skip-permissions --model opus"
alias cls="claude --dangerously-skip-permissions --model sonnet"
alias oc="opencode"
alias cx="codex"
alias ca="cursor-agent"
alias ct="continues"

# Docker
alias do="docker container"
alias dop="docker container ps"
alias dob="docker container build"
alias dor="docker container run --rm"
alias dox="docker container exec -it"

# Docker Compose
alias dc="docker compose"
alias dcu="docker compose up"
alias dcub="docker compose up --build"
alias dcd="docker compose down"
alias dcr="docker compose restart"

# Nix
alias ns="nix-shell"
alias ngc="nix-collect-garbage"
nrn() { nix run "nixpkgs#$1" "${@:2}"; }
alias ashiba="nfi github:yutakobayashidev/ashiba"
alias ndt="nfi github:the-nix-way/dev-templates"

# Security
scorecard() { GITHUB_AUTH_TOKEN="$(gh auth token)" command scorecard "$@"; }

alias p="pnpm"
alias ls="lsd -1A"
alias ll="lsd -l"
alias la="lsd -la"
alias lt="lsd --tree"
alias cat="bat"
alias gg="ghq get"
alias browse-pr="gh pr view --web"
alias isv='gh issue list | fzf-tmux --prompt "issue preview>" --preview "echo {} | awk '\''{print \$1}'\'' | xargs gh issue view -p" | xargs gh issue view'
